Do they fall in the edible range? They are so tiny …

results.notes:
This probable Amanita species is unusual in that the stem is very short and very broad. It is almost as wide as it is long !
The warts do not sit on top of the cap like many Amanita but the warts margins blend into the cap.
The spore print is white and microscopically they measure 11 to 13 microns in length. See images.

results.notes:
Collected near the Old Mitchell trail with Chance Noffsinger. Growing on conifer twigs and an adjacent dead, standing conifer trunks near Abies frasieri and Picea rubens. Caps light gray (2.5Y 7/2 in Munsell) over the entire disc or with a grayish brown over the center (10YR 5/2). finely innately fibrillose; becoming rimose in age; parabolic to campanulate to convex; dry; 4.8 to 17.0 mm wide and 4.0 to 7.9 mm tall. Gills white (10YR 8/2); brown-marginate; sinuate to adnexed; with 1 to 2 tiers of lamellulae; finely intervenose; 16 full-length lamellae reaching the stem. Lamellar edge not separable. Stems white (10YR 8/2) at the apex and pale brown (10YR 6/3) at the base. smooth and dry; equal or tapering toward the base; compressed; hollow; not producing latex when cut; 8.2 to 22.7 mm long and 1.0 to 2.4 mm wide at the widest. Basal mycelium white and strigose. Cap and stem context white. Odor and taste not distinctive. Pileipellis a cutis. Pileipellis and lamellar trama vinescent in Melzer’s reagent. Clamps present in the lamellar trama. Pleurocystidia absent. Cheilocystidia abundant, appearing hyaline, smooth and thin walled; shape variable: fusiform, lageniform or cylindrical; often apically branched and some subcapitate. Basidia 4-sterigmate and basally clamped. Spores immediately weakly amyloid; hyaline, smooth and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (7.6) 8.5 – 11.7 (13.3) × (4.5) 4.7 – 6.7 (7.6) µm; Q = (1.5) 1.53 – 1.8 (2.4); N = 30; Me = 9.9 × 5.7 µm; Qe = 1.7

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 133730617 on September 5, 2022.

results.notes:
On HCL+ sandstone bedrock, very common but only locally on this type of rock. This stands out as a very white looking Protoparmeliopsis because of the marginal lobes. The cortex is densely white pruinose over yellow-brown, and is K+Y, KC-, C-. The thalline margin is concolorous with the thallus, the disk is light to dark brown and epruinose. Epihymenium is orange-brown with POL+ crystals soluble in K. Amphithecial cortex is about 30µm wide at mid-hymenium, with POL+ crystals not soluble in K. Algae thick and lumpy across the base of the apothecia. Spores simple, hyaline, ellipsoid, ~9×5µ.

Everything fits well with L. argopholis except that the marginal lobes seem more well developed than typical.

results.notes:
Collection dry when received. Collected by Linda Burke. Growing on mossy bark of a tree stump in mixed woods. Gills decurrent. Stems with strigose white basal mycelium. Connected to white mycelium mats and rhizomorphs. Pileipellis a cutis with clamps. Clamps present in the lamellar trama. Lamellar cystidia absent. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores inamyloid, hyaline, smooth and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (4) 4.6 – 6 (6.4) × (2.7) 2.74 – 3.4 (3.7) µm; Q = (1.4) 1.5 – 2 (2.1); N = 18; Me = 5.5 × 3.1 µm; Qe = 1.8

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 133730789 on September 5, 2022.

results.notes:
Little brown mushrooms…

Found in garden (rich soil, possibly wood chips), November 21st 2021 (Fall, cold, wet).

Several specimens growing close together.
Size ~3 – 10 cm length, caps ~1 – 2 cm broad.

Spore print very dense, dark black colour.
Spore sizes length 11 +/- 1 um, width 6 +/- 1 um, Q ~1.7.
Spores dark brown colour under microscope, also small “nipple” present on ends.

Possibly Psathyrella genus? I have no idea, I am new to this all so would really appreciate feedback and advice :) Thanks!

results.notes:
On the arid foothills. On sandy soil, with sagebrush and grass.
White, the largest, 8 × 5 cm. Some nearly spherical w/o a subgleba, and some tapered down, plicated, with a compacted subgleba, and a pseudostipe.
Outer layer felty, white .15 cm and inner layer purple brown .15 cms.
Gleba white at first, then cream, purplish, and later like chocolate cake with a purplish tone.
Spores almost round, warty (4.5-6.0) x (4.5-6.0); capillitium threads 2.0 -5.0.; septate and breaking easy.; a few splitting dichotomously.

results.notes: This was found in heavy Gambel oak and pine duff. Has a blood red and splotchy pileus that appears unique from other Xerocomellus known from the region. It was located approximately 10 miles south of Flagstaff along road 253D just south of James Canyon and west of I-17. Specimen sent to Terri Clements.

results.notes:
Collected near the Old Mitchell trail. Growing on a mossy conifer log near Abies frasieri and Picea rubens. Caps dry. Gills short-decurrent and not marginate. Stems producing clear liquid when cut. Clamps present in the lamellar trama. Pleurocystidia absent. Cheilocystidia abnundant; some hyaline and some with brown intracellular content and dimorphic with a long and a short morphology. “Long” cheilocystidia lageniform to utriform and more abundant. “Long” cheilocystidia measurements: (33) 36.8 – 68 (83.6) × (10.1) 11.2 – 18.3 (19.2) µm; Q = (2.3) 2.6 – 6.7 (7.6); N = 30; Me = 53 × 14.4 µm; Qe = 3.8. “Short” cheilocystidia obovoid to ellipsoid to broadly clavate. “Short” cheilocystidia measurements: (12.3) 17.1 – 34.1 (54.8) × (9) 12.9 – 23.1 (25.4) µm; Q = (1) 1.1 – 1.8 (2.2); N = 30; Me = 25.2 × 17.2 µm; Qe = 1.5. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores hyaline, smooth and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (6) 6.7 – 8.2 (9.1) × (4.1) 4.4 – 5.6 (5.9) µm; Q = (1.3) 1.4 – 1.6 (1.7); N = 30; Me = 7.5 × 5.1 µm; Qe = 1.5

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 133730906 on September 5, 2022.

results.notes: Cladonia pocillum is one of many species in the genus, which is relatively easy to recognize (at least in moist state) in spite of the fact that it is very similar to much more common Cladonia pyxidata. Cladonia pocillum never forms large cushions. They are usually round or oval and only a few cm in diameter while Cladonia pyxidata may form much larger patches (but not at all always) of any imaginable form. Most distinguishing trait between both is large and vividly green (when moist), almost foliose, overlapping primary squamules, which form a ‘rosette’ around the colony. The central part of the colony often contrasts with the edges in color and shape. It is usually yellowish or brownish even if moist. Podetia are small, smaller than with typical well developed Cladonia pyxidata but are otherwise almost indistinguishable form podetia of Cladonia pyxidata. In dry state it is more difficult to separate both species.

results.notes:
On well rotted conifer wood in an Eastern hemlock-dominated mixed forest stand.
Pileus grayish brown, hygrophanous fading to tan when dry, 2.5 cm diameter, convex with a central depression – umbilicate, striate at margin. Pileipellis a cutis of interwoven hyphae approx. 5 uM in diameter. Stipe concolorous with pileus with a tuft of whitish hyphae at base, 3.5 – 4 cm long x 3mm diameter. Lamellae white to pale brown, adnate. Basidia 4-spored, clamped at the base. Basidiospores 4.5-5.5 (-6.0) x 3.5-4.5 uM, lacrymoid to ellipsoid, colorless, inamyloid, with a large central oil drop. Cheilocystidia undeveloped, indistinguishable from undeveloped basidia.
If you do a Blast search based upon the ITS-region barcode sequence, this collection comes up as Clitocybe subditopoda based upon several GenBank accessions clustered around JN021003 identified by Bryn Dentinger. I do not believe this is the taxon is the same as Clitocybe subditopoda Peck sensu Bigelow who examined Peck’s type (Bigelow, H. 1982. Species described in Clitocybe by C.H. Peck and W.A. Murrill. Sydowia 35: 65). According to Bigelow, Peck’s C. subditopoda has narrower spores (typically 2.5-3.5 and occasionally up to 4 uM) that are ellipsoid rather than lacrymoid and without the large oil drop (although this could be developmental stage-specific). The sequence of GenBank accession DQ202269 (deposited by Matheny & Hibbett based upon voucher PBM2489 (AFTOL-ID 533) from the eastern US) better matches Bigelow’s concept of C. subditopoda based upon Peck’s type and corresponds morphologically to Baroni’s description of C. subditopoda in Mushrooms of the Northeastern United States and Eastern Canada – see MO observation 457298 for more information. I think C. subditopoda Peck sensu Dentinger is not this species but I am unable to provide a better name. Morphologically, the gills in C. subditopoda Peck sensu Dentinger are adnate rather than subdecurrent.

results.notes:
On forest floor/litter under regenerating true fir and pine in a mixed wood with multi-age hemlock.
Spores amyloid, smooth, broadly elliptical to globose, 8-9.5 × 7.5-8.5 uM. Remeasured in water larger spores are 9.0-10.5 × 10-12 uM.
Basidia predominantly four-spored, 2-spored basidia uncommon, certainly much less than 50% as described for Amanita bisporigera, KOH reaction on dried basidiocarps faint yellow to reddish. Seems likely to be one of the 4-spored white Amanitas in Sect. Phalloideae although www.amanitaceae.org indicates that Amanita bisporigera can also be almost entirely 4-spored late in the season. Unfortunately I didn’t obtain a DNA sequence.

results.notes:
Field Description: Shelf fungi. Top is dark brown/black and has the texture of tree bark. Underside is tan with a smooth appearance but if you look closely it looks like there are many tiny pores. The cap is about 20cm wide, 8cm out from the tree trunk to the edge (measuring perpendicular to the tree) and ~5cm at its thickest point. It is growing on a black locust (Robinia pseudoacacia), which appears to be alive because it has green leaves and seed pods in its canopy. However, the black locust does have a big dead branch (~7cm diameter). This fungus is growing on the trunk at the base of the dead branch, so it is uncertain whether it is growing on live or dead wood. Directly beneath the fungus, there appears to be a rusty/brick-red/brownish powder that has fallen onto the tree and on the surface of some ivy leaves that are growing there. I have not examined this powder with a microscope, but I believe it to be an aggregation of spores that have fallen from the polypore.

Identification: With a few exceptions, the features of this specimen closely match the description of the Cracked-cap Polypore found on pgs. 476-477 of National Audubon Society Field Guide for North American Mushrooms (1981). The descriptions of general morphological features, spore color and habitat are consistent with my observations of this specimen. For example, the “Habitat” section on pg. 476 reads: “On living or dead black locust; reported on other trees in the same family.”, and the specimen is growing on a living black locust tree that has a large dead branch.

Other Notes: I initially identified this specimen as Phellinus rimosus (Berk.) Pil., using the Audubon field guide mentioned above. However, I am aware of at least two other names that have been used for this species. The first of these alternate names, Fomes rimosus, appeared in the “Comments” section of the aforementioned description of the Cracked-cap Polypore (i.e. from the Audubon guide). The second of these alternate names that I encountered is Fulvifomes rimosus (Berk.) Fiasson & Niemelä. After rejecting my initial attempt to create an observation with the scientific name: Phellinus rimosus, the Mushroom Observer website suggested Fulvifomes rimosus (Berk.) Fiasson & Niemelä as a “valid synonym.”

results.notes:
Collected by Brandon Matheny. Growing on soil among mosses in a narrow gulley. Near Abies balsamea, Picea sp., Pinus sp., Betula sp. and Acer spp. Caps smooth, dry and centrally depressed; 8.6 to 23.0 mm wide and 3.5 to 6.0 mm tall. Gills adnate to short-decurrent. Odor not distinctive. Taste farinose. Pileipellis a cutis with clamps. Clamps present in the lamellar trama. Filiform cheilocystidia present. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores amyloid and smooth. Spore measurements: (5.1) 5.7 – 7.1 (8) × (3.2) 3.4 – 4.4 (4.6) µm; Q = (1.4) 1.5 – 1.9 (2.1); N = 30; Me = 6.4 × 3.9 µm; Qe = 1.7

Collected along the Ski Jump trail. Growing among needle litter near Pinus spp., Abies balsamea, Picea sp., Fagus grandifolia, Betula sp., Thuja occidentalis and Acer sp. Caps viscid with a gelatinous pellicle; 39.1 to 42.4 mm wide and 8.0 to 9.1 mm tall. Stems 34.3 to 38.6 mm long and 7.6 to 11.3 mm wide. Odor and taste not distinctive. Pleurocystidia similar to cheilocystidia. Cheilocystidia fusoid-ventricose and hyaline in 10% Nh4OH. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores brown 10% Nh4OH, smooth, thick-walled and lacking distinct apical pores. Spore measurements: (5.8) 6.4 – 7.2 (7.8) × (2.8) 3.4 – 3.9 (4) µm; Q = (1.6) 1.7 – 2.1 (2.3); N = 30; Me = 6.7 × 3.6 µm; Qe = 1.9

results.notes: Many trees in my yard were taken by Dutch elm disease about 10 years ago. I used the fallen logs as landscaping borders and this year several logs produced these mushrooms. The first flush was in mid October, and were not noticed until they were already beginning to decompose. The second flush came in mid November. One log was brought indoors for observation because freezing temperatures threatened the fruit. The center of the cap turned greenish on some older specimens, but only on a few of them.

results.notes:
Under salicaceae, by the Boise river.
Small Hebeloma, very pale with a cream margin, almost one color, but with a yellowish center. Cap about 4cm., margin thin, incurved a little crenulated. Close notched gills, with the edge a little fringed; no guttation visible. Some fibrils of veil present around the gills, and around the top of the stipe. Stipe cylindric, woolly, with a white wider base. Smell raphanoid.
Spores 11.0 – 12.2 (14.0) x (6.0 – 7.0), Q aver=1.91; amygdaloid, rough, some slightly papillate.
Basidia 26 × 7.5. Cheilocystidia around 50 mics. slender; clavate to capitate, some with a slighly ventricose base; head 7.5-10, neck 4, body 6…
I am considering Hebeloma helodes as a separate species than H velutipes here.
